DetailContent.body: Hypertension is most commonly due to inappropriate depth of anaesthesia or inadequate analgesia. You should rapidly exclude a problem in adequate oxygen delivery, airway and breathing first.

DetailContent.head: Box A: CRITICAL CHANGES
DetailContent.body: If problem worsens significantly or a new problem arises, call for help and go back to START of key basic plan →1-1

DetailContent.head: Immediate actions
DetailContent.body: Recheck blood pressure AND increase anaesthesia AND reduce stimulus.

DetailContent.head: Adequate oxygen delivery
DetailContent.body:
• Check fresh gas flow for circuit in use AND check measured FiO₂.
  • Visual inspection of entire breathing system including valves and connections.
  • Rapidly confirm reservoir bag moving OR ventilator bellows moving.

DetailContent.head: Airway
DetailContent.body:
• Check position of airway device and listen for noise (including larynx and stomach).
  • Check capnogram shape compatible with patent airway.
  • Confirm airway device is patent (consider passing suction catheter).

DetailContent.head: Breathing
DetailContent.body:
• Exclude hypoxia and hypercarbia as causes
  • Check chest symmetry, rate, breath sounds, SpO₂, measured VTexp, ETCO₂.
  • Feel the airway pressure using reservoir bag and APL valve <3 breaths.

DetailContent.head: Circulation
DetailContent.body:
• Check rate, rhythm, perfusion; increase frequency of BP check.
  • Check cuff size and location, consider intra-arterial monitoring

DetailContent.head: Depth
DetailContent.body: Ensure adequate depth of anaesthesia and analgesia.

DetailContent.head: Box B: POTENTIAL UNDERLYING PROBLEM
DetailContent.body:
• Inadequate anaesthesia / analgesia (alfentanil can be diagnostic – see Box C for dose)
  • Inadequate neuromuscular blockade
  • Consider whether you could have made a drug error
  • Omission of usual antihypertensives
  • Distended bladder
  • Vasopressor administered by surgeon
  • Surgical tourniquet
  • Excess fluid (over-administration / overload / TURP syndrome)
  • Medical causes: drug interaction, renal failure, raised intracranial pressure, seizure, thyrotoxicosis, phaeochromocytoma
Call for help and consider temporising drug (Box C) if problem not resolving.

DetailContent.head: Box C: TEMPORISING DRUGS FOR HYPERTENSION
DetailContent.body:
• Alfentanil 10 µg.kg⁻¹ (adult 0.5-1 mg)
  • Propofol 1 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 50-100 mg)
  • Labetolol 0.5 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 25-50mg) repeat as necessary
  • Esmolol 0.5 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 25-50mg) follow with infusion
  • hydrALAZINE 0.1 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 5-10mg)
  • Glyceryl trinitrate 0.5-5 µg.kg.min⁻¹ infusion (adult 2-20 ml.hr⁻¹ of 1 mg.ml⁻¹ solution)

DetailContent.head: The guidelines in this handbook are not intended to be standards of medical care. The ultimate judgement with regard to a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the clinician in the light of the clinical data presented and the diagnostic and treatment options available.
